newsitem.title: ARGENTINA: Argentina's Menem calls TV probe reporters "liars".
newsitem.headline: Argentina's Menem calls TV probe reporters "liars".

text.p: Argentina's President Carlos Menem said on Monday that reporters behind an investigation into grandiose building projects in his tiny hometown were "miserable liars."
"These journalists are miserable liars. They made this (television) programme paid by some sector of the opposition," a visibly angry Menem said during a visit to the province of Cordoba.

The report on two houses, an airstrip and a zoo in Menem's hometown of Anillaco in the northwestern desert province of La Rioja, was taken off the air by private TV channel America 2 on Wednesday for fear of legal repercussions. It aired a day later amid a dispute about alleged censorship.

It raised questions about who paid for Menem's huge, pink ranch-style home in Anillaco, a nearby mountain refuge with heliport and artificial lake, a new full-length runway built by the air force -- for a town of just 850 -- and a zoo.

The 67-year-old president last week called it an "absurd" attempt to tarnish his "image, honesty and morality," and said on Monday it was "ridiculous to talk about impeachment because this president has done nothing wrong."

But the Radical and centre-left Frepaso opposition parties have sent delegations to La Rioja to investigate the allegations. Radical Party official Daniel Cohan returned from the province on Monday talking of "problems and anomalies."

America 2's suspension of the programme "Without Limits" last week because of what it said were legal concerns about the investigation by Roman Lejtman, a radio journalist who is a fierce critic of the Peronist government, forced Menem to publicly deny his government leaned on the broadcasters.

"My government has never put pressure on anybody to make them change the thrust of their programmes, information or commentaries," Menem said. Aides said he had been building his house for 12 years -- before he became president in 1989 -- while the airstrip was funded by private donations.
After apparently relenting and broadcasting the show late on Thursday, the America group's owner Eduardo Eurnekian then decided on Friday to scrap the series.

The episode has raised concerns about freedom of the press among Argentine journalists already fearful for their liberties since the murder a month ago of a photographer for the outspoken news magazine Noticias.
